SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
TABLING STATEMENT FOR REPORT ON HOSPITALITY INDUSTRY IN THE A.C.T.

On 22 January 1986 the Minister for Territories, the Hon. Gordon Scholes, MP, wrote to the committee suggesting that the committee inquire into and report on the state of the hospitality industry, its capacity to meet demand, prospects for its future and desirability and extent of government regulation.

The Minister's request was made in the context of hospitality and tourism being vital industries in the A.C.T. economy and furthering the government's objective of diversifying the territory's economic base.
The committee adopted the Minister's suggested terms of reference in February this year and conducted three public hearings as well as formal and informal inspections in Sydney and Melbourne.

The committee's inquiry is important in that it addresses major issues which have to be faced in the hospitality sector of the A.C.T. economy. This must be done in a way which will maximise the tourist potential generated by events surrounding the opening of Parliament House and bicentennial celebrations in 1988 and subsequent expansion of tourism in the territory.

Tourism is one of the main growth areas in the A.C.T. employing 4% of the workforce in A.C.T. restaurants, hotels and clubs. However, the industry's capacity to generate employment is greater than figures would indicate. Existing shortages will be aggravated by the completion of a number of new projects by 1988 including the New Parliament House, the Hyatt Hotel, formerly Hotel Canberra, the Pavilion Hotel on the site of the former Wellington Hotel and the White Industries Hotel convention centre. These new facilities could require as many as 1500 staff.

The question of staff shortage throughout the hospitality industry and the adequacy of existing training practices and facilities in the context of staff shortages and anticipated increase in demand for staff is examined in detail in the committee's report.

The committee found that the state of the hospitality industry varies significantly from one area to another. Accommodation is undergoing a period of significant expansion. Other areas such as restaurants are said to be experiencing stress resulting partly from excess capacity. The committee has examined the question of oversupply of restaurants and considers that this is a question best solved in the market place.

As well as commenting in turn on the various sectors included within the hospitality industry, the committee also examined in detail a new administrative structure to co-ordinate tourism and economic development in an effective manner.

A major recommendation of the committee is to amalgamate the present Canberra Tourist Bureau and the Canberra Development Board. The new board, to be known as the A.C.T. Development Board, will be responsible for promoting, developing and providing economic assistance to tourism and hospitality in the A.C.T.

In order to overcome past difficulties, this body should be established independently of the department of territories and have sufficient autonomy to react to changing needs and to provide immediate assistance to business when required.

The new board should be seen by private operators as a friendly and responsive organisation with sufficient flexibility to respond quickly to new developments and not be hampered by unnecessary bureaucratic procedures. It should also have direct access through its chairman to the Minister for Territories. The need for this body has been reinforced by the abolition of the House of Assembly.

To consolidate this new approach there is also a need to prepare a tourist development plan to indicate how planning and development policies affecting the hospitality industry may be co-ordinated in the interests of further development.

The tourist development plan would concentrate on overcoming deficiencies of present small scale and dispersed investments in tourism and identify areas where co-ordinated investment might yield the best returns.

The committee would like to ensure that the opportunities and challenges posed by the developments leading up to 1988 and the potential associated with the predicted growth in tourism in that year should not be missed.

Canberra in its role as the national capital is an obvious focus for a range of activities associated with the bicentennial celebrations and the opening of the New Parliament House. So that Canberra itself may derive maximum benefit from these developments it is essential that the key areas examined in this report, namely training and promotion, be addressed so that Canberra's economy may benefit from the domestic, national and international market potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The hospitality industry inquiry was set up at the request of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes). It was suggested that the Committee look into a number of things relating to employment awards and practices in the industry, the capacity of the industry to meet the demands, training of employees, the general health of the industry and its relation to tourism, which of course is an important part of the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. There are 22 recommendations but I certainly will not be referring to all of them, merely to some of them. Their thrust is the relationship between the hospitality industry and tourism and the need to promote both of them to assist in developing a more diverse economy in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee report refers, of course, to the fact that during the bicentennial year the new Parliament House will be opening. We recognise that that will add an attraction. We also recognise that, unless it is promoted, many Australians will not really appreciate that it is there. We do not believe that the new Parliament House will promote itself, as has been said on occasions. We certainly recommend the promotion of Canberra in the bicentennial context.

SPEECH.PARA: We have suggested that an Australian Capital Territory development board be set up incorporating the Canberra Tourist Bureau and the Canberra Development Board. In a sense one might say that that is merely shuffling the chairs and to an extent it might be. We are suggesting that both of those bodies be extracted from the somewhat lowly place they have fallen into within the structure of the Department of Territories and have a status which is more meaningful to the job that needs to be done, both in terms of development of business in Canberra and the development of tourism. We recommend that this board have direct access to the Minister because in the States tourist bureaus have direct access to a Minister. That is not the case here and we feel it is one of the reasons why tourism does not have the necessary profile.

We talk about the need for more low cost visitor accommodation. There are a number of beneficial recommendations on the hospitality industry which I trust the Government will implement quite quickly. We have suggested that the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority be provided with the necessary resources to conduct adequate inspections of licensed premises. Associated with that is the need to police under-age drinking. The present situation in the Australian Capital Territory is that we do not have a police force large enough to undertake that itself. It is necessary and, given the income earned by the Gaming and Liquor Authority through the licensing system, we believe that resources should be made available to see that this form of inspection is done properly.

We have raised again the need for the extension of the premises at the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education food school. That, of course, is nothing new. It was a big issue in 1982 and into 1983. It was with considerable disappointment that we found that that extension was not funded in the 1983 Budget because I think most people at the time recognised the need for it in relation to extending the facilities of the food school to provide training for young people in an area where jobs would be available, especially in 1988 with the opening of the new Parliament House and what we hope will be a boost to the tourist industry. We re- commend, as a matter of urgency, that that extension proceed, and that TAFE and the National Capital Development Commission give the highest priority to the project. It is not necessary to go over the correspondence back as early as 1981 and 1982 about the need for it.

We have also dealt with the question of the need to make young people more aware of the good jobs offering in the hospitality industry. There is a bit of a problem in the sense that people tend to think of the hospitality industry as one in which people are merely waiters of one kind or another. That is certainly a very important part of the employment in the industry but it really goes a great deal further than that. It was the Committee's hope that by the time we have a five star hotel in Canberra there will be a general increasing awareness of the prospects within the industry. We feel that the Schools Authority can, within its system, help to promote an awareness of the hospitality industry. We certainly hope that will occur as we see very good prospects indeed for a number of skilled jobs in the industry as time goes on.

We have dealt with another matter which is certainly not new, and that is that we recommended the introduction of a group apprenticeship scheme in cooking. A group apprenticeship scheme exists in Canberra in the building trade and is working most successfully. Many restaurants which are very good are quite small and a group apprenticeship scheme would mean that young people would get the opportunity to be apprentices in the industry and to get opportunities for learning in a number of different types of restaurants. I do not think I need spell out in detail how it would work, but certainly I trust that the necessary arrangements will be made for that to come into effect very quickly.

We recommend the introduction in 1987 of pre-employment courses by the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education as part of a revised course structure. I know that it is not long until 1987 but I do hope that will be able to be implemented. We have recommended that arrangements be made within the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education to set up a scheme whereby the food school can earn revenue and retain it. At present, if the food school earns any money, it goes into Consolidated Revenue. There are many ways in which a food school needs to run services so that students get practice. We visited Ryde and had a lunch which the students had prepared and provided as part of the process of learning to present food and run a restaurant. The same thing could be done here without additional revenue cost to taxpayers if a scheme were devised whereby the earnings from such a place were able to be recycled.

We have suggested a change in the ratio of apprentice cooks to chefs. It has been one to three in the past and we are suggesting that that be reduced in a way that will enable smaller restaurants to have apprentices, which has been overlooked in recent times. We want it done properly so that it is a quite legal arrangement. We have made recommendations in relation to junior rates of pay. Some of these things in relation to hours of employment, et cetera, have not gone as far as perhaps I would like to see them to nor as far as I would like change to occur when we are in government, but I recognise that that is not possible at present. It is my hope that what has been recommended, which, as I say, in some respects does fall short of what I prefer, will be implemented and be of benefit to those in the industry so that at least we can have some changes which will get on with providing more opportunities and more jobs in this area.

We have suggested the waiving of payroll tax on the salaries of junior employees. We have urged permanent part-time employment in the industry and we have certainly urged the Department of Territories to look at the workers' compensation system in the Australian Capital Territory. Again that is not the first time that has been suggested, but we lend our weight to that proposal. It has been an extensive inquiry. I think it has gone a fair way and I certainly look forward to the implementation of the recommendations and an early response by the Government. I would be disappointed if most of them were not looked at quite quickly. I would hope that in time some of them would go further than they have. I wish to thank the staff who assisted the Committee with this inquiry. There were a number of submissions and witnesses. I note that the other senator for the Australian Capital Territory is present. I am sure that she would be very interested in this report when she reads it. Many of the things we have recommended are matters that I know are well known to her and I look forward to her using her influences to see to the early implementation of our recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I had an addendum to this report in the nature of a minority report. I support most of the recommendations and I certainly support what Senator Reid has been saying, but I was concerned about one aspect of the recommendations which I felt should have been advanced and that was to do with the wage rates payable under the current wage system in the hospitality industry. The problem is that for the hospitality industry in the Australian Capital Territory to expand in the face of its travel problems-I will come to those in a few moments-and in competition with capital cities, it has to provide absolutely first class service at modest prices seven days a week and 24 hours a day, and the hospitality industry in the Australian Capital Territory needs to have that reputation known right around Australia and, indeed, internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: The report makes it quite clear that that service is not available at competitive rates under the current wage system. The report concedes that inordinately high penalty rates at weekends and public holidays are a disincentive to the provision of services and hence to employment in the industry. I recognise that total deregulation of wages in the hospitality industry would create the fear in the minds of some people that it might lead to what is called `sweat shop' conditions, but I do believe that it is necessary in this industry to adopt awards which would enable an hourly rate of pay to be payable throughout the week-a week of seven days and 24 hours each day. It may very well be that, as a result of market forces operating, that wage would be variable at weekends and in the evenings, but that generally opportunities would be created for service if there were an hourly rate of pay payable as a minimum across the board 24 hours a day, seven days a week instead of these excessively high penalty rates that apply under the awards. What is happening is that employers in those circumstances are simply not employing staff over weekends or at night, so the service is not available. Accordingly, I have recommended that employers and employees in this industry in the Australian Capital Territory be free to enter into agreements as to wages and conditions outside awards, save that such agreements must provide for at least the relevant award rate of pay calculated at the hourly rate for ordinary weekly hours of work.

I mentioned the travel problem for the Australian Capital Territory. It must be recognised that Canberra is off the main tourist routes but that it is an attractive venue for both Australian and foreign tourists. The problem is to keep the tourists in the Australian Capital Territory for more than a brief visit. There is more that tourists can see and do in Canberra than just take one hour to visit the National Gallery and one hour to visit the Australian War Memorial. That is not enough time to look at the national park and other areas around Canberra which are not currently on the main tourist routes. The de- restriction of bus services to Canberra will help very much but the major problem arises with the air fare regulation and control and, unfortunately, lack of promotion by the industry in the Australian Capital Territory. I was unable to make any recommendation in this area other than to draw the matter to people's attention.

Finally, I have to say that I cannot agree with recommendation 19 which recommended that junior rates of pay apply only to permanent employees. That would mean that non-permanent employees who are of a young age would have to be paid adult rates of pay. That seems once again to be a total hindrance to opportunities being created for young people in the Australian Capital Territory to get into this industry. It is a growth industry; there are opportunities for good careers in it and I think that every opportunity should be taken for young people to be encouraged to go into it. The way to do that is to enable employers to employ young people at a rate of pay which is acceptable to the employer. There is a bottom which is created by unemployment relief. Young people would not be expected to work for anything less than the rate of unemployment relief. Nevertheless, if there were deregulation of junior rates of pay I am sure there would be many more opportunities for young people to enter this industry. Accordingly, I cannot agree with recommendation 19.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS AND THE POLISH PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the parliamentary delegation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the Polish People's Republic 1986, together with two supplementary reports. I seek leave to make a brief statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit to the Soviet Union and Poland represents the third visit to the USSR in the last 20 years and the second visit to Poland in the same period by an Australian parliamentary delegation. The delegation spent 11 days in the Soviet Union visiting Leningrad, Tashkent and Samarkand in addition to Moscow. It then travelled to Poland for a further 11 days visiting major centres in the north and south of Poland as well as Warsaw. The report which I have tabled draws attention to the principal meetings in which the delegation participated and highlights the major issues raised. The report records a wide range of meetings during the visit at the national as well as regional levels. During these meetings we discussed a wide spectrum of subjects. However, throughout these meetings our common message was clearly our concern for peace and disarmament, for human rights and family reunions. In the Soviet Union this included the treatment of Soviet Jews.

SPEECH.PARA: It was quite interesting that at just about every place we went at the conclusion of the speech by whoever was welcoming us we were given a dissertation on peace. If the parliamentary delegation visited a provincial town the mayor would welcome us, give us the statistics, tell us what a wonderful place it was and give us a lecture on peace. It was as though peace was something that belonged to the Soviet Union, something tangible that only it had in a little box and something that other nations should try to have. Every time we had an opportunity after such a lecture we told the Soviet Union that it could not have international peace unless it had international justice, unless people were free to worship as they wished and unless people were free to leave any country they wished.

Other major topics of discussion included Australia's commitment to the Western alliance, the Chernobyl accident, industry and agriculture and the balance of trade with Australia. The delegation was indeed fortunate in being able to meet His Excellency Andrei Gromyko at the Grand Kremlin Palace in Moscow and General Jaruzelski at the Seym in Warsaw as well as senior government representatives and regional officials throughout the visit. On two occasions we had unofficial meetings, one in Poland and one in Moscow. These were in our own time and were not official. Firstly we met with the refuseniks and members of the Jewish community in Moscow and in Poland we met with members of Solidarity and the Catholic church. As an addendum to the report I have tabled are two supplementary reports dealing with those meetings.

I would like to thank our hosts in the Soviet Union and Poland for the warmth and generosity of their hospitality extended to the delegation during its visit. We made no bones about the fact that Australia is very much part of the Western alliance. However, I think both countries sensed that Australia had a lot to offer the world and that we had an independent streak about us. I also pay tribute to the staff of our embassies in Moscow and Warsaw for the enormous efforts made and the assistance provided during our visit. I mention in particular Ambassador and Mrs Pocock, Mr Ahudja and Mr Denton in Moscow, Ambassador and Mrs Hughes, Mr McKenzie and Ms Wieniawska in Warsaw. On behalf of the delegation, I also express our gratitude to the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office for their work prior to the visit and afterwards in getting the report together for tabling.

I express gratitude to Dr Frank Frost and the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library for the enormous effort they put into the delegation brief. I doubt whether another delegation has gone overseas with such a good and comprehensive brief as that with which we were provided by the Parliamentary Library. I think all members of the delegation spoke of the effort the Library put into the brief and the depth of information in it.

As the deputy leader of the delegation I pay tribute to Madam Speaker who led the delegation. At all times she was in charge and she let the government of whichever nation we were speaking to know that we were a delegation which had very definite views especially on its record on human rights. I recall some Soviet officials talking to her and saying: `But you are such a nice woman, why are you so tough?'. That was the way Madam Speaker played it and I pay tribute to her leadership. Obviously members on any parliamentary delegation are a diverse group; they come from many different political and philosophical backgrounds. In this instance, I pay tribute to all members of the group because when we were discussing various aspects with members of other governments we worked as a team; they saw us as a team because we let them know in no uncertain terms that even though we were from different political backgrounds there were certain matters on which we were one. The rest of the delegation played a good role. I express my personal thanks to all members of the delegation for their support and friendship during the visit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was a member of the parliamentary delegation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Poland. I join Senator Collard in his appreciation of Mrs Joan Child as the leader of the delegation. She did a magnificent job in sometimes very difficult circumstances. She represented Australia very well and gave the governments of the Soviet Union and Poland a good insight into what a very tough and thoughtful Australian woman can do. I think we were amazed at the firmness with which she approached her job. I also thank Kieran Schneemann who wrote the report and accompanied the delegation. He was a pillar of strength. We worked very diligently and had very little rest. The delegation was held together by the actions of Kieran Schneemann.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collard placed some emphasis on the Soviet's preoccupation with peace. I think with some justification the Soviets are preoccupied with peace because they lost 20 million people in World War II. If we as a nation had suffered as the Soviet Union suffered in World War II I think we would be far more interested in real peace than we are. We talk about peace, but we have never had our homes destroyed or members of our families killed. This was brought home most powerfully to us when we visited Leningrad. At the Piskarevskoye Cemetery we saw in an area of just a few hectares the mass graves of 640,000 people. So many people were killed in so short a time during the German siege of Leningrad that they could not be buried in normal cemeteries. Altogether the Russians lost one million people in Leningrad.

We saw expressions of grief that people hold even now. It is customary for a wedding party to visit some cemetery or memorial and present the bridal bouquet because, as I mentioned before, everybody lost someone in that war. So they know the meaning of war. Therefore, universally, the people of the Soviet Union want peace. We may disagree with the way in which some of their military leaders want to obtain peace, the same as we disagree with the way in which some of the military leaders of the United States of America are trying to obtain peace. But I feel that the people of the Soviet Union sincerely do crave peace.

I was interested to find that some of my conceptions about the Soviet Union were misconceptions. I found that the people in general-I would say about 90 per cent of them-are probably quite happy. They are certainly better off than they were under either the Tsar or Stalin. I would say that the average Russian, who is probably interested in soccer and perhaps a bit of vodka-and there is not as much of that flowing as there was-is probably quite happy. But probably 10 per cent are quite unhappy. Probably the part of Soviet life that distressed me most was the question of dissent. If I lived in the Soviet Union I would not be allowed to dissent in the way that I do in Australia. I brought this up with many of the Soviet leaders. I said: `Look, I think you are sincerely interested in peace, but you have to open up your society to those who disagree with the present policies'. I believe that this is in fact happening. I think Mikhail Gorbachev is actually trying to open up the society under his policy of glasnost. I think attempts are being made to remove the disadvantages that exist in Soviet society.

It is interesting to note that in Tashkent a member of the Supreme Soviet of Tashkent told us that it was not enough simply to produce items. They could meet their production quotas but what they had to concentrate on now was quality. He told us that it was no good producing things that people would not buy. This was an incredible statement for someone to make in the Soviet Union. Just a few years back, anybody who said such a thing would be shipped off to Siberia. Such a pronouncement can now be made openly. So I think the Soviet Union is changing, and I think it is changing for the better. Certainly, there are restrictions on movement and speech. However, I think it is changing. It disturbs me really that we do not recognise this change.

One thing that was particularly interesting to me, as a former American, was the reaction of the Soviet people to Americans. We attended the very moving opening of the Goodwill Games in Moscow. This was a complete spectacle-extravaganza. One of the features of the games was a mock re-enactment of the docking of the Soyuz and Apollo space vehicles when the Russian astronauts and the American astronauts actually met in space. This was done by means of full-size mock rockets going up cables which were attached to balloons and then a meeting of the two capsules on cables between the balloons. At the same time an astronaut from the Soviet Union who had been in Soyuz and an astronaut from the United States who had been in Apollo were brought in in open-top cars. They shook hands. Gorbachev was at the Games, along with 100,000 other people. At all times the United States and the Soviet Union were given equal billing. This would not happen in the United States. As an American, I was taught to hate all Russians and all communists. I was taught to despise them. The people of the Soviet Union are not taught to despise Americans. They are taught to despise Reagan and the Administration, but not the entire American people. I took this as a very positive sign.

People are always saying to me: `Okay, you are always calling for world peace. You are always protesting at the presence of American warships and American nuclear weapons. Why don't you do something in Russia?' Well, I did so in the Kremlin. In the presidium of the Supreme Soviet I suggested universal disarmament. I Said: `Look, Mikhail Gorbachev has won great acclaim around the world with his test ban proposal. Why don't you go one step further and start withdrawing your weapons?'. As we know, there are 50,000 nuclear weapons around the world. All the military planners know that there are far more military weapons than are needed for any military victory and that we have enough to kill everyone on earth many times over. I said: `How about withdrawing your weapons unilaterally, because if you do so I am sure that world public opinion will pressure the United States to follow?'. I was interested in the response. One very old member of the Presidium across from me beat his fist on the table and said: `Nyet, nyet'. But the younger people looked thoughtful and nodded, which I took as a good sign.

I think there is hope in the Soviet Union. I think we must understand that the Soviet society is changing. It is loosening up and it is changing for the better. I think we must also understand that our society is tightening up. I foresee a time when actually our two societies will be similar. We are losing our rights and our basic freedoms and the people of the Soviet Union are gaining more of theirs. We will probably end up at pretty much the same level in the next 10 years or so.

I was impressed with Poland. I was somewhat surprised when I was told about the past lack of unity in that country. We learnt that Poland has been a complete country for very little of its history and for most of the time had been occupied by someone or other. It was very interesting to find how proud the people of Poland are to be a unified nation for the first time in many hundreds of years. I think this explained a lot about the Poles' fierce loyalty to their country. We were privileged to travel widely in Poland. We travelled some 3,000 kilometres by bus and were very well received by the Poles. I think we learnt a lot from them and I hope they learnt from us. More attention must be paid to Poland; it is a country in deep need. We must be more aware of its problems and more willing to help. The Poles are desperately in need of any kind of technological help we can give them. They are in need of outlets for their manufactured goods. We must do everything we can to help them rebuild their economy. Although the economy is shattered, there is great hope and potential in Poland. I will not delay the Senate. I am very thankful to the Parliament for making it possible for me to go on this trip. I learnt a lot-I hope we all did-and I am very thankful that this report has been prepared in the excellent way it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to join my colleagues in thanking our hosts for their hospitality. I certainly enjoyed every day I spent in the Soviet Union and Poland. I was very pleased to be a member of the parliamentary delegation visiting the Soviet Union and Poland in June and July of this year. This was not my first visit to the Soviet Union; I was there 10 years ago. This was the first time I had visited Poland. The report of the delegation is a fair recollection of the findings of the delegation, and I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make just a couple of brief reflections. Some members of the delegation had a unique opportunity to meet independent peace movement people in Moscow who were not involved in the official peace movement in the Soviet Union. It is no secret that the possibilities for open dissent in the Soviet Union are limited. This group of people had questioned their Government's increasing reliance on nuclear power and called on their Government, in a positive way, to look for other forms of energy generation. Those people made it quite clear to us that they were not against their Government but they wanted it to look at other sources of energy. They had demonstrated on this and had been charged with anti-Soviet activities, but they were able to use the Soviet judicial system and have their actions considered by the courts on much less drastic charges. I thought this was a most significant development because I doubt whether some years previously they could have used the judicial system in the manner in which they are using it today. I concur with Senator Sanders and say yes, there are changes, and I for one perceive many changes there.

I would like to make a comment on human rights in the Soviet Union. The delegation at every opportunity raised human rights issues with the Soviet officials. It is true to say that the inquiries were not always entirely welcomed, but we were heard out, there is no doubt about that. I can say that the people who initiated the human rights questions were from the left wing of our Party. It is very easy to gain applause in this country for being prepared to raise in the Soviet Union the question of human rights. But there are enormous pressures operating against similar questions being raised against so-called friendly countries in our region. Instead, we are asked to excuse the unacceptable behaviour in those countries as being the result of cultural differences. I believe that justice and human rights everywhere are essential to the achievement of peace. Peace will be achieved only when we are prepared to ask the hard questions of our friends as well as of those who seem to be regarded by some as enemies.
I would like again to thank the Soviet Union and Poland for their hospitality. I thoroughly enjoyed my stay there. I certainly learnt a lot in both countries, and for this I am grateful.

PIG INDUSTRY BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill and the two associated Bills-the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment (No. 2) Bill 1986 is to restructure the statutory arrangements for the Australian pig and pigmeat industry. This Bill establishes an Australian Pork Corporation to replace the existing Pork Promotion Committee, and establishes an Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee, to nominate suitably qualified persons for appointment to the Corporation, and an Australian Pig Industry Policy Council to provide a forum where matters of concern to the industry as a whole can be discussed and appropriate policy options developed.

During the past ten years the Australian pigmeat industry has made many significant advances. These are best illustrated by the increase in pigs slaughtered from 3.4 million in 1974-75 to an estimated 4.5 million in 1985-86. The gross value of production in the same period has risen from $197 million to $450 million. Domestic per capita consumption of pigmeat has risen from 12.9kg to over 16kg. These are growth rates of which any industry would be proud.
It is appropriate that such a dynamic industry should review its organisational structure to ensure that it is relevant to today's needs and the requirements of tomorrow.

The Australian pig industry has been concerned for some time that the legislation creating the Pork Promotion Committee has not been sufficiently broad to enable that body to become involved in marketing initiatives on behalf of the industry as a whole. This has included such developments as Computer Aided Livestock Marketing (CALM) and the development of a National Livestock Language (AUS-MEAT). In both these initiatives the interests of the beef and sheepmeat industries have been represented by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC). If the pig industry is to be fully involved in either of these schemes it will be necessary to place the responsibility in the hands of a statutorily funded body.

In discussions with the industry on the most suitable structure for industry organisations, a number of options were put forward, one of which was to bring the marketing of pigs and pigmeat within the scope of the AMLC. Serious consideration was given to this option but in the end the pig industry decided it wanted to remain independent of the AMLC.

After lengthy discussion with the industry the package contained within this legislation was developed and accepted by the Australian Pork Producers' Federation as the most suitable that could be achieved.

The new Australian Pork Corporation will have a wider range of functions and powers than the present Pork Promotion Committee. This will enable it to become involved in marketing issues affecting the industry where it feels such involvement is necessary and desir- able. The Corporation is not intended to be a trading body or to involve itself in any form of price setting mechanism that would restrict competition in the market place.

The Corporation will have the power, on behalf of the pig industry, to participate in and contribute financially to marketing arrangements such as CALM or AUS-MEAT should, if in the commercial judgment of the Corporation, such schemes appear to be in the interests of the industry.

The Corporation will consist of seven members, there will be an independent Chairperson, a Commonwealth Government Member and five members selected for their expertise in such matters as pig production, pigmeat processing, product from promotion, marketing or appropriate commercial skills.

The five members will be selected by an Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee. This Committee will have four members; an independent Chairperson, two members nominated by the Australian Pork Producers' Federation and one member nominated by the National Meat Processors Association (NMPA).

Policy development within the industry is to be strengthened by the formation of an Australian Pig Industry Policy Council. The purpose of the Council will be to enquire into and report to the Minister and the industry about matters affecting the well being of the industry and to develop recommendations and plans for measures to further the interests of the industry.
The Council will be made up of:
An independent Chairperson
The President and Senior Vice-President of the Australian Pork Producers' Federation
The President of the National Meat Processors Association
The Chairperson of the National Smallgoods Council
The President of the Stockfeed Manufacturer's Association of Australia
The Chairperson of the Australian Pork Corporation (APC); and
The Chairperson of the Pig Research Council.

The new arrangements are to be financed from levies collected on pigs slaughtered in Australia for human consumption. There will be no implications for Commonwealth finances arriving from the legislative changes.

The legislation governing the operations of the new bodies is in line with the guidelines laid down in the Governments policy statement ``Reform of Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities'' which I tabled on 20 January 1986.

The accountability of the Corporation has been strengthened by requiring the Corporation to report at least once a year to the executives of the APPF and the NMPA. At such meetings the whole range of APC activities can be discussed. This accountability to industry is in addition to the usual requirement for an annual report to Parliament.

The APC is to be responsible for making recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry on the rate of the pig slaughter levy for the APC. In making such recommendations the Corporation will be required to consult with the APPF and the NMPA and will be required to inform the Minister of the views of those bodies when requesting an increase.

The APC will be required to prepare and submit for approval by the Minister for Primary Industry a three to five year corporate plan setting out its broad objectives for the period and its proposed strategies for achieving those objectives.

In addition the APC will be required to prepare an annual operating plan setting out its strategies, programs and proposed resource usage for the year. Again this annual plan will need to be approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.

The sections of this Bill Associated with the selection of the members of the APC come into force on the day it receives the Royal Assent and the rest of the Bill will be proclaimed when the selection process has been completed and the new Corporation is ready to proceed.

In concluding I would like to pay tribute to those members who have served on the Pork Promotion Committee since its inception in 1975. The progress and achievement of the industry to which I referred earlier are, I am sure, in no small measure due to the work of the Committee and the promotional activities it has organised.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986
The purpose of this Bill which is associated with the Pig Industry Bill 1986 is to provide for the financing of the Australian Pork Corporation.
The portion of the Pig Slaughter Levy that, until now, has been paid to the Pork Promotion Committee will, in the future be paid to the new Corporation.

The Bill also raises from $1.00 to $1.50 per pig, the maximum rate of levy that can be collected for the new Corporation, although it is not intended to increase levies to that level at this time. The Bill has no effect on the operative rate of levy nor does it impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
PIG INDUSTRY (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill which is associated with the Pig Industry Bill 1986, is to provide a smooth transfer of functions from the Pork Promotion Committee to the new statutory structure for the pig industry detailed in the Pig Industry Bill 1986.

The arrangements will have no impact on Commonwealth revenue as the Bill provides that costs associated with selection of members for the new Corporation will be met by the Pork Promotion Committee which is financed solely by a levy on pigs slaughtered.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
